headline: Despite Early Criticism, Apple’s iOS 7 Quickly Gains Traction
abstract: Despite harsh criticism from some designers, app developers and tech journalists about iOS 7, Apple’s redesigned mobile operating system, people are downloading the software in droves.

headline: Dow Index Drops Bank of America, Alcoa and H.P.
abstract: Alcoa, Bank of America and Hewlett-Packard — three stalwarts of corporate America that have fallen out of favor lately with investors — will be removed from the Dow Jones industrial average, to be replaced by Goldman Sachs, Visa and Nike.

headline: Today in Small Business: Frauds and Cyberattacks
abstract: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.

headline: Morgan Stanley Beats Estimates
abstract: Morgan Stanley’s adjusted second-quarter earnings narrowly beat analysts’ estimates. | A special committee of Dell’s directors may delay a vote on the company’s proposed sale. | JPMorgan Chase is trying to avoid a showdown over accusations that it manipulated energy prices. | Nelson Peltz urges a merger of PepsiCo and Mondelez International.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Origin of Google Docs, and Spying on Your Own E-Mail
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selections include a look at the evolution of Google Documents, and a way to see how much information can be gleaned from looking at a Gmail account but not inside the messages.

headline: Buy! Sell! Hold! Analysts Offer Different Views on Apple
abstract: After Apple extended sales of the iPhone to new foreign markets and offered a less expensive iPhone, some analysts downgraded the company’s stock while others came to its defense.

headline: The ‘Coase Theorem’ and Labor Unions
abstract: Ronald Coase, in his research and theories, found in labor unions many of the qualities valued by his more liberal colleagues, an economist writes.

headline: Wall Street Gears Up for a Twitter I.P.O.
abstract: Four big banks — with Goldman Sachs taking the lead — are said to have secured roles in Twitter’s highly anticipated initial public offering, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Dell Buyout Bid in Peril as Voting Rule Remains
abstract: A special committee of Dell Inc.’s board said on Wednesday that it would be willing to accept the latest takeover bid by its founder, worth $13.75 a share, if he dropped his demand for a change to the voting rules.

headline: Rocket Fuel Prices I.P.O. at Top of Revised Range
abstract: Rocket Fuel, an advertising technology company that relies on artificial intelligence, priced its initial public offering on Thursday at the top of its expectations, garnering $116 million in proceeds.

headline: Barclays Names Top Aerospace Banker
abstract: Barclays has announced that Jay Caldwell will join the bank as global head of its aerospace and defense team.

headline: Workday Weaves In Big Data
abstract: The cloud-computing, corporate software company extends its reach with analytics software aimed at “mere mortals.”

headline: Chinese Internet Giant Alibaba Plans to Issue I.P.O. in New York
abstract: Ownership rules prevented the company from making its highly anticipated, and potentially very lucrative, debut in Hong Kong, as it had wished

headline: Strauss-Kahn Joins Investment Firm
abstract: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund whose career was damaged by a series of sexual scandals, will join an investment banking boutique based in Luxembourg.

headline: Hiring the Well-Connected Isn’t Always a Scandal
abstract: Several companies have explicit policies against cronyism, and hiring a family member simply for a relationship can be troubling and may not necessarily serve a company’s interests. But that doesn’t mean the children of powerful people aren’t always qualified candidates.

headline: How Pay-Per-Gaze Advertising Could Work With Google Glass
abstract: Google was awarded a patent last week that many think could connect Glass with advertising. But a patent is one thing; turning that into a feature could take a while.

headline: Bank of America Profit Surges
abstract: Bank of America posts second-quarter net income of $4 billion. | Michael S. Dell is engaged in last-minute maneuvers over the company he founded. | Hiring a company’s former executive as a buyout adviser can present problems, the Deal Professor writes. | Paolo Pellegrini gets testy on the witness stand in the trial of Fabrice Tourre.

headline: SAC in Settlement Talks
abstract: Federal prosecutors and SAC Capital Advisors are said to be in settlement talks. | Alibaba has shifted its initial public offering plans to New York from Hong Kong. | JPMorgan Chase is negotiating a multibillion-dollar settlement with state and federal agencies over its sale of troubled mortgage securities before the financial crisis.

headline: New Claims in U.S. Case Against SAC Ex-Trader
abstract: Federal prosecutors filed an updated indictment in the criminal insider trading case against a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, adding a claim that he received secret information about drug trials from a second doctor.

headline: Cohen of SAC in the Spotlight
abstract: Regulators argue that Steven A. Cohen knew about and took part in suspicious trading activity at SAC. | A maneuver by financial players adds a fraction of a penny to the price of aluminum cans. | The governing Liberal Democrats in Japan secured a landslide victory in parliamentary elections. | A revelation in Detroit illustrates a broader debate over pension math.

headline: Families of Gang Rape Convicts Cry Foul
abstract: “This is a government conspiracy,” said the mother of one of the four convicts, after hearing the verdict in the Delhi gang rape case on Tuesday.

headline: Office Advancement vs. Home Duties
abstract: Fewer parents today say they want more responsibilities in their jobs than did so in 1992. Perhaps changing gender roles are at play.

headline: Lessons From a Famous Bet
abstract: A conversation with Paul Sabin, author of a new book on a storied 1980 wager over the prospect of overpopulation — and the applications for the current debate over global warming.

headline: Twitter Adds CBS to Its Stable of Big Advertising Partners
abstract: As the social network prepares to sell stock to the public, it is trying to show sustained revenue growth. Under Twitter’s Amplify program, CBS and other broadcasters can pair video clips with ads and distribute them on the service.

headline: BlackBerry’s Prospects Are Muddied
abstract: A BlackBerry co-founder is weighing a possible bid for the troubled company. | JPMorgan Chase’s general counsel once called for more corporate accountability when he worked as a regulator. | Vivendi and Activision Blizzard have been tripped up on their new deal by their old one.

headline: Technology Workers Are Young (Really Young)
abstract: In case you could not figure it out from the cubicle dogs and Nerf guns, a vast number of the workers in the technology industry are young and male. How young may surprise you: a new survey shows the top tech companies have a median work force age up to 15 years below the national average.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Sizing Up Google
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday’s selections feature a pair of Google product reviews and a theory about why Zynga folded on the gambling business.

headline: My Search for a Smart Way to Share Profits
abstract: My previous practice had been to hand out bonuses when I felt “rich and happy.” But that seemed arbitrary.

headline: At Sun Valley, Watching to See if the Chatter Is More Than Idle Talk
abstract: The Allen & Company media and technology conference is best known for the deals that have emerged from hush-hush meetings that take place in the ensuing months.

headline: The Question of Taxing Employer-Provided Health Insurance
abstract: There’s little likelihood that Congress will consider eliminating the highly popular tax exemption for employer-provided health benefits, even though that would be good policy, an economist writes.

abstract: Chancellor Leo Strine of Delaware’s Court of Chancery also defended the work by a special committee of Dell’s board, saying that its actions benefited shareholders.

headline: Oracle’s Next Cloud Moves
abstract: Oracle, the large enterprise software company, will kick off one of the industry’s biggest customer conferences with a lot of news.

headline: Lessons From the Emergency Room
abstract: Is it possible to build a company from scratch and also maintain a good work-life balance?

headline: Fast Food Versus Slow Food
abstract: While the time costs of preparing meals at home can be high, these costs go way down when cooking for several people at a time, an economist writes.

headline: Fund Responds to Chief’s Prostitution Arrest
abstract: Common Sense Investment Management, a $2.9 billion fund of funds based in Oregon, sought to distance itself on Wednesday from a prostitution scandal involving its chief executive.

headline: S.E.C. Rejects Its Own Deal With Hedge Fund Manager
abstract: The decision to overrule its own enforcement division’s proposed settlement with the high-flying money manager Philip A. Falcone signals a broader crackdown by the agency.

headline: Dutch Bank ABN Amro Takes Step Toward an I.P.O.
abstract: The announcement comes five years after the Dutch government bailed out ABN Amro after a consortium of European banks acquired the firm for around 72.2 billion euros, or $99 billion.

headline: Union Push for I.P.O. Forces Filing at Chrysler
abstract: Chrysler is taking the step toward an offering only under pressure from its second-largest shareholder, a trust set up to provide medical coverage for 115,000 retired auto workers and family members.

headline: Amgen Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Onyx for $10.5 Billion
abstract: The biotech giant Amgen is near a deal to buy Onyx Pharmaceuticals, a maker of cancer-fighting drugs, for about $125 a share, people briefed on the matter said on Saturday.

headline: Intersection: Keeping Cool on Wall St.
abstract: Jose De Haro skips the suit on most days, but pays special attention to fit and tailoring when dressing for his broadcast job on Wall Street.

abstract: Although the White House is delaying a provision requiring employers to offer health coverage or pay a penalty, the key aspects of the Affordable Care Act should be little affected, an economist writes.

headline: Daily Report: Bitcoin and Other Virtual Currencies Face Legal Scrutiny
abstract: State and federal officials are starting broad investigations into shortcomings in the oversight of upstart virtual currencies like bitcoin.

headline: When Cheating Is Ignored
abstract: Enron and Italy: The cheating was known, but viewed as unimportant. And that was a serious mistake.

headline: Why Italy Could Be Fertile Ground for Deal Makers
abstract: Italy’s shaky state should not be an insurmountable obstacle to foreign investment, the author writes. Foreign deal makers just need to find ways to coax Italy’s aging entrepreneur-owners to the table.

headline: Tip of the Week: Test-Drive Android Apps Online
abstract: Amazon’s store for Android apps has a Test Drive feature that lets you see an app in action before you buy or download it.

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selections include a battery-powered exoskeleton for the legs that can help elderly or disabled people walk, and people who buy cellphones in bulk from thieves to be sold around the world.

headline: A New Divestment Focus on Campus: Fossil Fuels
abstract: Concern over global warming has spurred students to dust off investment choice as a weapon in their campaign. But whether it will be as effective this time is another matter.

headline: An Ex-Trader, Now a Sociologist, Looks at the Changes in Goldman
abstract: “What Happened to Goldman Sachs” examines the bank’s evolution from an elite private partnership to a vast public corporation – and the effects of that transformation on its culture.

headline: Hollywood’s Biggest Bang for Its Buck
abstract: A look at which film genres have the biggest return on investment.

abstract: A month after the Himalayan floods, Indian officials declare 5,748 persons missing.

Plus, are viral videos of cute animals fueling a black market for them?

headline: Apple Buys 2 Mapping Companies
abstract: Apple confirmed on Friday that it had bought the mapping start-ups HopStop and Locationary, giving Apple more expertise in an area where it has struggled.

headline: U.S. Regulators Approve Stricter Trading Rules Overseas
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission voted 3-1 to rein in lucrative trading by American banks doing business overseas, but the agency also afforded Wall Street additional time to comment on the plan to phase in the regulation, inviting an onslaught of lobbying from banks.

headline: Marines Share Frank Views with Hagel on Women in Combat
abstract: Fifteen female Marines sat down with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel to discuss the Pentagon’s new decision to integrate women into front-line combat positions.

headline: Firms to Pay $14 Million to Settle
abstract: D.E. Shaw and Deerfield Management were among the firms that have agreed to pay a total of $14.4 million to the agency.

headline: A Conversation With: Goa Chief Minister Manohar Parrikar
abstract: Mr. Parrikar describes the 2002 Gujarat riots as an administrative failure and claims that unlike his Bharatiya Janata Party colleague Narendra Modi, who governs Gujarat State, he would not have let it happen.

headline: Daily Report: T-Mobile US Expands Its Customer Base
abstract: T-Mobile US, the fourth-largest American phone carrier, said it had gained 1.1 million customers during its second quarter.

headline: Q&A: Revealing Your Location (or Not) to Mobile Apps
abstract: Mobile apps may have useful reasons for requesting your location information, while others just want to show you local advertising.

abstract: The government is said to be poised to announce the indictment of SAC Capital, the hedge fund led by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, which could lead to the fund’s demise.

abstract: What do you think? Are the business owners protesting paid sick leave laws overreacting?

headline: Q&A: Adding Pictures to the Windows 8 Photos App
abstract: The Photos app in Windows 8 can show off the pictures on your computer, as long as you have those pictures in the right place.

abstract: After years of only listening to music on services like iTunes, Spotify and Pandora, radio suddenly becomes more appealing for its human element.

abstract: Only one in three Americans has confidence in the Federal Reserve’s ability to promote economic growth.

abstract: James W. Giddens, the court-appointed trustee liquidating the bankrupt firm, told vendors they had until Friday to defend payment they had received.

abstract: Steinway’s biggest shareholder, Samick Musical Instruments of South Korea, disclosed in a regulatory filing on Wednesday that it too had bid for the piano company, offering $39 a share.

abstract: Dell has bought itself six more days to win backing for its proposed $24.4 billion sale to its founder, but the fight for additional support remains tough.

abstract: A Stanford researcher has found that innovation steeply declines after a company goes public. What does that mean for Twitter?

abstract: The attack on Prabhjot Singh, an assistant professor at Columbia University, is jarring because Harlem has a deep history of solidarity between various communities.

abstract: The prospect of Nokia shedding its core business – the longtime pride of Finland – weighed heavily on the potential deal.

headline: Hear That? It’s Your Financial Adviser Tweeting.
abstract: Raymond James plans to announce an extensive effort to help its thousands of financial advisers harness social media when contacting clients.

headline: Dreams of a Mother
abstract: The struggles and ambitions of a domestic help in Delhi.

headline: The Free-Trade Blues
abstract: The optimistic view that increased foreign trade benefits everyone works only if winners fully compensate losers, and so far they have shown little desire to do so , an economist writes.

headline: Remote Controls, Without the AAA Batteries
abstract: A company in San Diego, Maxwell Technologies, says it has developed a power system for remote controls that stores electricity without chemicals and can recharge in minutes.

headline: Activision in $8.2 Billion Deal to Buy Back Stake From Vivendi
abstract: The deal represents the latest corporate maneuver for Activision’s chief executive, an entrepreneur who built the company into a giant with a market capitalization of nearly $17 billion.

headline: Datto, a Data Backup Service, Raises $25 Million in Round Led by General Catalyst
abstract: Datto, which provides both local and cloud-based data backup and continuity services, plans to announce on Tuesday that it has raised $25 million in its first-ever round of venture capital financing, led by General Catalyst Partners.

headline: S.&P.’s Counterattack on the Government
abstract: In its defense against a Justice Department lawsuit, Standard & Poor’s argues that it was improperly targeted because it lowered the credit rating on federal debt two years ago. How far it will get with that argument is an open question.

headline: Water Wars in India’s South
abstract: The two south Indian states of Kerala and Tamil Nadu are battling over a 112-year-old reservoir.

headline: Despite Early Criticism, Apple’s iOS 7 Quickly Gains Traction
abstract: Despite harsh criticism from some designers, app developers and tech journalists about iOS 7, Apple’s redesigned mobile operating system, people are downloading the software in droves.

abstract: Alcoa, Bank of America and Hewlett-Packard — three stalwarts of corporate America that have fallen out of favor lately with investors — will be removed from the Dow Jones industrial average, to be replaced by Goldman Sachs, Visa and Nike.

abstract: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.

abstract: The number of federal employees who report working part time because they cannot get full-time hours — a sign they might be on furlough — remains high.

abstract: Doctors in Chennai in the southern state of Tamil Nadu are considering the rare possibility of “Spontaneous Human Combustion” in the case of a three-month old boy.

headline: Citigroup to Pay Fannie Mae $968 Million Over Mortgage Claims
abstract: Citigroup said on Monday that it had agreed to pay Fannie Mae $968 million to resolve potential claims on 3.7 million mortgage loans from 2000 to 2012.

abstract: Profit of $1.9 billion in the second quarter sounds like a return to the good old days at Goldman Sachs. But the firm hasn’t managed to solidly outpace rivals.

abstract: Federal authorities are poised to level criminal charges against SAC Capital Advisors. | Yahoo seems like damaged goods now that it has been abandoned by Daniel S. abstract: The American drug company Perrigo agreed on Monday to acquire the Irish biotechnology company Elan in a cash-and-stock deal worth $6.7 billion.

abstract: A $606 million buyout of the company by its founding family received support from 81 percent of the voting power of the outstanding shares.

headline: Rebels Delay Peace Talks in Colombia
abstract: The move by the group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, complicates negotiations to end Latin America’s longest-running guerrilla war.

headline: Battling Superstition, Indian Paid With His Life
abstract: The killing of Narendra Dabholkar, a former physician who aimed to drive skepticism into India’s superstition, is the latest episode in a wrestling match between traditionalists and reformers.

headline: Ron Motley, Who Tackled Big Tobacco, Dies at 68
abstract: Mr. Motley helped lead litigation in the early 1990s on the health consequences of smoking, leading to the largest civil settlement in American history: $246 billion.

headline: A Silicon Valley for Ad Agencies, Only in the Mountains
abstract: Project WorldWide is opening an agency in Boulder, Colo., which is developing a reputation as a home for advertising start-ups.

headline: Ballmer Exit Brings Microsoft a Chance for Reinvention
abstract: Steven A. Ballmer’s departure paves the way for a generational change at Microsoft and gives it an opportunity to adapt to a world dominated by technologies that have eluded its influence.

headline: Obama and Advisers to Discuss Syria
abstract: The White House is expected to discuss reports of a chemical weapons attack by the Syrian government and how the United States might respond.

headline: Despite Early Criticism, Apple’s iOS 7 Quickly Gains Traction
abstract: Despite harsh criticism from some designers, app developers and tech journalists about iOS 7, Apple’s redesigned mobile operating system, people are downloading the software in droves.

headline: Dow Index Drops Bank of America, Alcoa and H.P.
abstract: Alcoa, Bank of America and Hewlett-Packard — three stalwarts of corporate America that have fallen out of favor lately with investors — will be removed from the Dow Jones industrial average, to be replaced by Goldman Sachs, Visa and Nike.

headline: Today in Small Business: Frauds and Cyberattacks
abstract: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.

headline: Morgan Stanley Beats Estimates
abstract: Morgan Stanley’s adjusted second-quarter earnings narrowly beat analysts’ estimates. | A special committee of Dell’s directors may delay a vote on the company’s proposed sale. | JPMorgan Chase is trying to avoid a showdown over accusations that it manipulated energy prices. | Nelson Peltz urges a merger of PepsiCo and Mondelez International.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Origin of Google Docs, and Spying on Your Own E-Mail
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selections include a look at the evolution of Google Documents, and a way to see how much information can be gleaned from looking at a Gmail account but not inside the messages.

headline: Buy! Sell! Hold! Analysts Offer Different Views on Apple
abstract: After Apple extended sales of the iPhone to new foreign markets and offered a less expensive iPhone, some analysts downgraded the company’s stock while others came to its defense.

headline: The ‘Coase Theorem’ and Labor Unions
abstract: Ronald Coase, in his research and theories, found in labor unions many of the qualities valued by his more liberal colleagues, an economist writes.

headline: Wall Street Gears Up for a Twitter I.P.O.
abstract: Four big banks — with Goldman Sachs taking the lead — are said to have secured roles in Twitter’s highly anticipated initial public offering, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Dell Buyout Bid in Peril as Voting Rule Remains
abstract: A special committee of Dell Inc.’s board said on Wednesday that it would be willing to accept the latest takeover bid by its founder, worth $13.75 a share, if he dropped his demand for a change to the voting rules.

headline: Rocket Fuel Prices I.P.O. at Top of Revised Range
abstract: Rocket Fuel, an advertising technology company that relies on artificial intelligence, priced its initial public offering on Thursday at the top of its expectations, garnering $116 million in proceeds.

headline: Misgivings About How a Weed Killer Affects the Soil
abstract: Some farmers are examining their soil, and finding cause for concern after years of using glyphosate to kill weeds in their fields.

headline: Jennifer Lawrence to Star in ‘East of Eden’ Remake
abstract: The “Hunger Games” director Gary Ross plans to make two movies based on the John Steinbeck novel.

headline: U.N. Deal on Syrian Arms Is Milestone After Years of Inertia
abstract: In the most significant diplomatic initiative of the Syrian civil war, five key nations have agreed on a resolution saying Syria must give up its chemical weapons, but the statement lacks the threat of force.

headline: A Guide to the New Exchanges for Health Insurance
abstract: Details on the Obama administration health care plan are scheduled to be disclosed next week, but it’s never too early to examine the basics.

headline: Chinese Court Sentences Celebrity Singer’s Son to 10 Years for Rape
abstract: Li Tianyi, 17, and four other defendants were convicted in a case that stirred discussion about the reckless lives of some offspring of China’s elite.

headline: Population Control Is Called Big Revenue Source in China
abstract: Nineteen local governments in China collected a total of $2.7 billion in fines last year from parents who had violated family planning laws, a lawyer who had requested the data said.

headline: A Shaken Kenya Is Hit Again in 2 Deadly Attacks by Militants
abstract: Three people were killed in attacks on police officers near the border with Somalia. The Kenyan authorities blamed the Shabab militant group, which has taken responsibility for the mall siege.

headline: Answers to Readers’ Questions About Hiring the Right Candidate
abstract: The Times invited readers who work as managers or own their own businesses to ask Jay Goltz, a columnist for You’re the Boss, questions about hiring candidates.

headline: Rebels View Coalition Leadership Outside Syria as Detached From the Suffering
abstract: While the main opposition group’s leaders shuttle among fancy hotels, they seem increasingly powerless to affect the course of the war.

headline: Day Devoted to Hoisting Guinness Starts to Leave a Bitter Taste
abstract: Critics say Arthur’s Day, which began in 2009 to mark the 250th anniversary of Guinness, is nothing but an excuse for binge drinking.

headline: Kenya Presses Assault Against Militants in Mall Siege
abstract: The Kenyan military announced Sunday night that it had retaken most of the Nairobi mall that had been stormed by Shabab militants a day earlier and freed more hostages, though details could not be confirmed.

headline: Merkel Re-elected in Show of Strong Support for Party
abstract: The surprising show of strength for the chancellor and her center-right Christian Democrats might just translate into an absolute parliamentary majority, highly unusual in Germany.

headline: Typhoon Weakens as It Heads Toward Chinese Mainland
abstract: The storm started veering away from Hong Kong and toward the Chinese mainland, but Hong Kong residents were warned  to take precautions.

headline: Typhoon Kills at Least 25 People in China, Reports Say
abstract: A powerful typhoon that had threatened Hong Kong brushed past, but crashed into a mountainous area of Guangdong Province, according to the local news media.

headline: An Escape From Slavery, Now a Movie, Has Long Intrigued Historians
abstract: Solomon Northup told a story of escaping from slavery in 1853, and for decades scholars have been trying to untangle the truth of his account.

headline: Detroit Is Now a Charity Case for Carmakers
abstract: General Motors, Ford and Chrysler are investing heavily in plants from Mexico to China. Yet their operations in Detroit remain a fraction of what they were a half-century ago.

headline: Strong Chinese Manufacturing Data Points to Turnaround
abstract: The initial HSBC purchasing managers index for September shows expansion accelerating to a six-month high.

abstract: The Haggler ventures into Microsoft’s customer service network, and has an update on a backpack that was pronounced dead, despite a lifetime warranty.

headline: Fox Contest Offers 30-Second Super Bowl Pregame Ad as a Prize
abstract: The contest is meant to tap into public interest in the advertising for the game by using social media to pick a winner. The entry fee is $150,000, however.

abstract: The actors behind your favorite commercials.

abstract: The world will be watching to see whether President Obama and President Hassan Rouhani of Iran find a way to connect at the United Nations on Tuesday.

headline: Vote for Merkel Seen as Victory for Austerity
abstract: For months, Europe waited for German elections, hoping that a re-elected Chancellor Angela Merkel would ease austerity measures. The wait is over, and so, too, is any hint of a new approach.

abstract: A Russian government-owned conglomerate said it would sell to two private investors just under half of the company that makes Kalashnikov assault rifles.

headline: Mexico Passes a Weakened Bill to Evaluate Teachers
abstract: For the first time, teachers would undergo mandatory evaluations, for example, but analysts said violent protests had led Congress to include provisions  that might undermine the new legislation.

headline: In Nokia, Microsoft Bets on Apple-Like Revival
abstract: Microsoft’s predicament recalls the situation Apple found itself in during the early 1990s, with high-quality products overlooked in the marketplace.

abstract: A federal court in Washington blocked one service from streaming the networks’ programs until a copyright infringement lawsuit concludes.

headline: Irving Azoff Starts New Entertainment Business
abstract: The multifaceted company, backed by $175 million from the Madison Square Garden Company, will be called Azoff MSG Entertainment.

headline: Prices Are Rising for New Homes, and the Land They Are Built On
abstract: Land brokers and development companies in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area are reporting that after years of no growth, the price of land is increasing rapidly.

headline: Acxiom Lets Consumers See Data It Collects
abstract: Visitors to the site can review many seemingly innocuous facts about themselves, but critics say it provides a sanitized view of the information mining behind data-driven marketing.

headline: Opposition Lawmaker Arrested in Treason Plot in South Korea
abstract: The lawmaker, Lee Seok-ki, who is affiliated with the far-left United Progressive Party, became the first South Korean politician arrested on the criminal charge of plotting treason.

abstract: The parliamentary defeat for Prime Minister David Cameron that led him to rule out British military participation in any strike on Syria reflected fears of action against Damascus without certain evidence.

abstract: The suspect, Yasin Bhatkal, is a founder of Indian Mujahedeen, a group tied to explosions in New Delhi, Mumbai and other major cities.

abstract: The central bank acted at a hastily called meeting to protect the nation’s currency, which has slumped to its lowest level since April 2009.

abstract: The Obama administration says the information it will make public will show proof of a large-scale chemical attack by Syrian forces.

abstract: As the Sudanese government has been slow to respond, critics say, the members of Nafeer, a volunteer youth-led initiative, have taken phone calls and headed out in trucks to deliver bags of aid.

abstract: Hostels, long associated with backpackers and students, have gone upscale and now attract business travelers, especially young ones on tight budgets.

abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron will be weakened at home and abroad after Parliament refused to support his effort for military intervention in Syria.

abstract: Using a technology called augmented reality, carmakers can embed images and video over a picture on a smartphone or tablet.

abstract: The prosecution of Siert Bruins, who served as a border guard in Adolf Hitler’s elite Waffen-SS troops, is part of an effort in Germany to bring elderly former Nazis to justice before it is too late.

abstract: Despite an international effort to block it, Syria’s governing Assad family exploited large loopholes, lax enforcement and a far greater emphasis on limiting the spread of nuclear arms.

abstract: David Blech, who was once biotechnology’s top gunslinger and was worth about $300 million, is about to begin a four-year prison term, having pleaded guilty to stock manipulation.

abstract: The State Department order appeared to reflect concerns about possible strikes on American targets by Syrian government allies.

abstract: President Obama emerged from the Group of 20 summit meeting with a few international supporters, but other leaders urged him not to attack without United Nations backing.

abstract: An administrative court also banned four satellite networks considered sympathetic to supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.

abstract: President Obama’s standing has undoubtedly suffered from recent turmoil over Syria and American spying, even though he can point to a strengthening economy.

headline: Rodman, Leaving North Korea, Says Prisoner Issue ‘Not My Job’
abstract: The former basketball star Dennis Rodman on Saturday professed his admiration for North Korea’s dictator while angrily rejecting calls that he use his pull to help a detained American.

headline: Afghanistan and Pakistan Release Taliban Militants
abstract: The release of the prisoners, including a Taliban commander who was arrested in 2008, comes as both the Afghan government and the Taliban have been demanding that such militants be let go.

headline: China: Official Denies Taking Bribes
abstract: Lei Zhengfu, a former Communist Party official in the city of Chongqing, insisted during an appeals hearing on Friday that he had not taken bribes.

headline: As Summers’s Odds Rise, Stimulus Easing Is Seen
abstract: Anticipation that Lawrence H. Summers will be President Obama’s choice to lead the Federal Reserve Board has some investors speculating about a faster withdrawal of stimulus.

headline: A New Leader but a Familiar Scene in Australia
abstract: On Saturday, voters delivered a defeat to the Labor Party and picked Tony Abbott as prime minister. But on Sunday, they found a couple of customary sights on television.

headline: On Both Sides, Syrians Make Pleas to U.S.
abstract: As lawmakers prepare to debate a strike on the Assad government, Syrians on both sides of the issue work to influence Congress and the American public.

headline: Police at British Palace Stop a Stranger: Prince Andrew
abstract: Days after an intruder was captured inside Buckingham Palace, the police accosted Prince Andrew on Wednesday evening for wandering on the palace grounds, apparently without identification.

headline: ‘PBS NewsHour’ Begins Its Overhaul
abstract: “PBS NewsHour” has added weekend newscasts and is set to introduce its new weeknight team with Gwen Ifill and Judy Woodruff, the first female co-anchors at any network.

headline: Paul Scoon, Who Invited Grenada Invaders, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Scoon was appointed to the ceremonial post of governor general of Grenada before playing the role of power broker when the United States invaded his Caribbean nation.

headline: A Reinvented Condé Nast Traveler Sets a New Course
abstract: A print and social media campaign for the revised magazine will carry the theme “I am a Traveler” with the subtheme, “Every Journey Begins Here.”

headline: Despite Early Criticism, Apple’s iOS 7 Quickly Gains Traction
abstract: Despite harsh criticism from some designers, app developers and tech journalists about iOS 7, Apple’s redesigned mobile operating system, people are downloading the software in droves.

headline: Dow Index Drops Bank of America, Alcoa and H.P.
abstract: Alcoa, Bank of America and Hewlett-Packard — three stalwarts of corporate America that have fallen out of favor lately with investors — will be removed from the Dow Jones industrial average, to be replaced by Goldman Sachs, Visa and Nike.

headline: Today in Small Business: Frauds and Cyberattacks
abstract: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.

headline: Morgan Stanley Beats Estimates
abstract: Morgan Stanley’s adjusted second-quarter earnings narrowly beat analysts’ estimates. | A special committee of Dell’s directors may delay a vote on the company’s proposed sale. | JPMorgan Chase is trying to avoid a showdown over accusations that it manipulated energy prices. | Nelson Peltz urges a merger of PepsiCo and Mondelez International.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Origin of Google Docs, and Spying on Your Own E-Mail
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selections include a look at the evolution of Google Documents, and a way to see how much information can be gleaned from looking at a Gmail account but not inside the messages.

headline: Buy! Sell! Hold! Analysts Offer Different Views on Apple
abstract: After Apple extended sales of the iPhone to new foreign markets and offered a less expensive iPhone, some analysts downgraded the company’s stock while others came to its defense.

headline: The ‘Coase Theorem’ and Labor Unions
abstract: Ronald Coase, in his research and theories, found in labor unions many of the qualities valued by his more liberal colleagues, an economist writes.

headline: Wall Street Gears Up for a Twitter I.P.O.
abstract: Four big banks — with Goldman Sachs taking the lead — are said to have secured roles in Twitter’s highly anticipated initial public offering, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Dell Buyout Bid in Peril as Voting Rule Remains
abstract: A special committee of Dell Inc.’s board said on Wednesday that it would be willing to accept the latest takeover bid by its founder, worth $13.75 a share, if he dropped his demand for a change to the voting rules.

headline: Rocket Fuel Prices I.P.O. at Top of Revised Range
abstract: Rocket Fuel, an advertising technology company that relies on artificial intelligence, priced its initial public offering on Thursday at the top of its expectations, garnering $116 million in proceeds.

headline: Senior Chinese Official Falls Under Scrutiny as Some Point to Larger Inquiry
abstract: Jiang Jiemin is the first full member of the elite Central Committee to be publicly singled out on corruption charges under the country’s leader, Xi Jinping.

headline: No Clear Winner in Debate Between Merkel and Challenger
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel and her Social Democratic rival, Peer Steinbrück, fought each other to a virtual draw in their sole television debate of the German election campaign.

headline: Iraqi Camp for Iranians Faces Deadly Clashes
abstract: The circumstances of the violence, which left at least 15 people dead, were contested by the Iraqi government and representatives of the group of dissidents.

headline: A Data Broker Offers a Peek Behind the Curtain
abstract: The Acxiom Corporation plans to open a Web site that will allow individual consumers to see some of the information that the company has collected about them.

headline: Breaking Up With ‘Breaking Bad’ Is Hard for Albuquerque
abstract: The popular series, which showcased Albuquerque’s grit and high-desert beauty, has helped the city become a star in its own right and given rise to an entire “Breaking Bad” economy.

headline: The Bridges Are New, but Business Scams Are Timeless
abstract: A survey suggests that surprising numbers of Americans don’t recognize potentially fraudulent sales pitches — and that the rich are sometimes the most easily fooled.

headline: Iranians Welcome Home Rouhani With Protest
abstract: Protesters hurled eggs and a shoe at President Rouhani as he returned from the United Nations, while supporters cheered him for reaching out to President Obama.

headline: Intel and Sony Ambitions for Internet TV Services Meet Skepticism
abstract: Intel’s goal of introducing its OnCue service by the end of the year has been scrapped, and Sony, like Intel, has yet to announce deals to carry any channels.

headline: Resignations in Italy Put Government in Crisis
abstract: The withdrawal of five ministers from the coalition government sets off a new crisis that could put Europe’s stability at risk.

headline: Making iOS 7 More Readable
abstract: Enlarging the system type on your devices, and installing software when you have no CD drive on your laptop.

abstract: Looters plundered stores on Wednesday as Acapulco struggled to recover from a flood wrought by a tropical storm that is also threatening Cabo San Lucas.

headline: Iran’s Leaders Signal Effort at New Thaw
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani capped a series of gestures from Iran’s ruling establishment by saying the country would never “seek weapons of mass destruction, including nuclear weapons.”

headline: Why Philip Molyneux Never Left Sony
abstract: Mr. Molyneux, head of Sony Electronics in San Diego, says he has been given freedom to innovate, create and build.

headline: Getting Out the Word on Twitter
abstract: How to post public and private replies on Twitter, and security software for Windows 8.

headline: Rift Deepens Over Latest Plan for Europe’s Banks
abstract: A senior European Central Bank official took a jab at the German finance minister, accusing him of blocking revisions to the ’s troubled banking system.

abstract: Weapons experts and diplomats say that if President Bashar al-Assad is serious about giving up his arsenal, he will have to take dramatic action in the coming weeks.

headline: Robert Gates to Write ‘Duty,’ About His Time as Defense Secretary
abstract: The book promises to explore the “contrast between my public respect, bipartisanship and calm, and my private frustration, disgust and anger.”

headline: A Befuddling Game Show Slides, Despite ‘Synergies’
abstract: A strategy known as “symphony” — in which NBC liberally salts its broadcasts with promotions — seems to have had little effect in drawing viewers to “The Million Second Quiz.”

headline: How Syria Media Advisers Decided Who Would Speak to President Assad
abstract: After Charlie Rose broadcast an hourlong talk with Bashar al-Assad on PBS, George Stephanopoulos of ABC was invited to do the same, but the rug was pulled out from under him.

headline: Politico Plans for New York Are Drawing Some Doubt
abstract: Some wonder if there is room in the city for another political and media Web site, even if it is made in the image of successful Politico.

abstract: In a joint appearance, Robert M. Gates and Leon E. Panetta were critical of President Obama for asking Congress to authorize the use of force against Syria in retaliation for its use of chemical weapons.

abstract: Witnesses have described soldiers from the Sudan People’s Liberation Army indiscriminately firing on market squares, beating people and raping women.

abstract: Fox’s new series about a reincarnated Ichabod Crane had a big audience for its premiere; and ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” showed some life.

abstract: The tepid ratings for Simon Cowell’s two-year-old show are yet more evidence that singing competitions are not the blockbusters they once were.

headline: New Metric for Colleges: Graduates’ Salaries
abstract: PayScale offers an alternative to the U.S News rankings of universities, listing them by the average earnings of their graduates. Not everyone agrees with that approach.

abstract: The Federal Reserve is trying to reassure investors about its effort to stimulate the economy as it prepares a shake-up of its policy-making committee.

abstract: Ads will begin to run on Friday for “The Spoils of Babylon,” a six-part series about a wealthy oil family that will parody mini-series of the 1970s and ’80s.

headline: Labor Dept. Reports Plunge in Jobless Claims, Then Says Figures Were Flawed
abstract: The number, the government said, was skewed by upgrades on two state computer systems that caused those states to underreport claims.

abstract: Some brands pass on conventional advertising like commercials or print ads to stand out and to motivate consumers to become customers.

abstract: Mobile devices can be powerful personal finance tools, with apps that make managing and paying bills easier, if not more enjoyable.

abstract: How to move photos from iPhoto to Aperture, and how to update a Google Calendar invitation.

abstract: The actions are jeopardizing the national economy and tightening world oil supplies at a time when unrest is spreading in the Middle East.

abstract: The announcement by Secretary of State John Kerry and the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, set the stage for one of the most challenging undertakings in the history of arms control.

abstract: Despite a 2012 deal with the largest group of Muslim insurgents, factionalism complicates peace efforts on Mindanao, experts say.

abstract: The police moved to reclaim a historic square in Mexico City two days before the nation’s Independence Day celebration is to be held there.

abstract: The magazine is updating a number of sections and redrawing its typeface, though the magazine says it will still be identifiable to longtime readers.

abstract: The top United Nations human rights official, Navi Pillay, is concerned that the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, is stacking a human rights panel with political appointees.

abstract: Damascus’s Old City has been largely unscathed by war, but a New Jersey man raised there is helping arm and organize militias to protect the historic district.

abstract: A self-described technocrat, Mr. Colombo curbed roaring inflation, battled political extremism and legalized divorce in his country while helping to build an integrated Europe.

abstract: The dead man was identified as a student at a Palestinian Authority security academy in Jericho.

abstract: A rocket carrying satellites crashed moments after liftoff, sending a cloud of highly toxic fumes toward nearby towns as unspent fuel burned off.

abstract: That the government enacted a law aimed at compelling adult children to visit their aging parents is yet another sign of the monumental changes sweeping through Chinese society.

abstract: Photoshop is now the biggest-name software that you can’t actually buy, as the new version costs $30 a month, or $240 a year.

abstract: The minister, Delphine Batho, had said in a radio interview that the proposed 2014 budget, which would cut 7 percent from her ministry, was “bad.”

abstract: Fox News dominates in total audience, but among younger viewers its lead is slipping. The arrival of Ms. Kelly, after a maternity leave, could help.

headline: Dow Index Drops Bank of America, Alcoa and H.P.
abstract: Alcoa, Bank of America and Hewlett-Packard — three stalwarts of corporate America that have fallen out of favor lately with investors — will be removed from the Dow Jones industrial average, to be replaced by Goldman Sachs, Visa and Nike.

headline: Today in Small Business: Frauds and Cyberattacks
abstract: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.

headline: Morgan Stanley Beats Estimates
abstract: Morgan Stanley’s adjusted second-quarter earnings narrowly beat analysts’ estimates. | A special committee of Dell’s directors may delay a vote on the company’s proposed sale. | JPMorgan Chase is trying to avoid a showdown over accusations that it manipulated energy prices. | Nelson Peltz urges a merger of PepsiCo and Mondelez International.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Origin of Google Docs, and Spying on Your Own E-Mail
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selections include a look at the evolution of Google Documents, and a way to see how much information can be gleaned from looking at a Gmail account but not inside the messages.

headline: Buy! Sell! Hold! Analysts Offer Different Views on Apple
abstract: After Apple extended sales of the iPhone to new foreign markets and offered a less expensive iPhone, some analysts downgraded the company’s stock while others came to its defense.

headline: The ‘Coase Theorem’ and Labor Unions
abstract: Ronald Coase, in his research and theories, found in labor unions many of the qualities valued by his more liberal colleagues, an economist writes.

headline: Wall Street Gears Up for a Twitter I.P.O.
abstract: Four big banks — with Goldman Sachs taking the lead — are said to have secured roles in Twitter’s highly anticipated initial public offering, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Dell Buyout Bid in Peril as Voting Rule Remains
abstract: A special committee of Dell Inc.’s board said on Wednesday that it would be willing to accept the latest takeover bid by its founder, worth $13.75 a share, if he dropped his demand for a change to the voting rules.

headline: Rocket Fuel Prices I.P.O. at Top of Revised Range
abstract: Rocket Fuel, an advertising technology company that relies on artificial intelligence, priced its initial public offering on Thursday at the top of its expectations, garnering $116 million in proceeds.

headline: S.E.C. Advances New JOBS Act Rule, but Not Crowdfunding
abstract: The JOBS Act set the end of last year as the deadline for final rules on crowdfunding, but the S.E.C. has not yet proposed those regulations, much less completed them.

headline: Khuzami’s New Job
abstract: Robert S. Khuzami, formerly of the S.E.C., has accepted a job at Kirkland & Ellis. | Telefónica agrees to buy Germany’s smallest mobile operator. | Federal regulators have begun an examination of commodities warehouse controlled by financial firms. | Why did Steven A. Cohen pay so much to settle a case that now appears far from settled?

headline: The Affordable Care Act and Part-Time Work
abstract: A model comparing the expected and actual rates of involuntary part-time work indicates that the health care law has not had a significant effect, an economist writes.

headline: Disruptions: Gawker Wants to Encourage More Voices Online, but With Less Yelling
abstract: A site that will promote comments on Gawker Media sites wants to elevate the role of commenters while trying to keep needless vitriol at bay.

headline: Faces of Pakistan
abstract: Multiple facets of Pakistan as a nuclear armed country as it celebrates its 67th year of independence.

headline: Today in Small Business: Health Care Confusion
abstract: Sales of vinyl records increase. A guide for small businesses looking to hire I.T. project managers. Why you shouldn’t be loyal to your bank.

headline: F.C.C. Clears Sprint Deals With SoftBank and Clearwire
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission on Friday cleared the way for the $21.6 billion purchase of Sprint by SoftBank of Japan, as well as Sprint’s offer to buy the broadband network Clearwire.

headline: In Ad Merger, a Boon for Two Smaller Banks
abstract: The $35.1 billion merger of Publicis and Omnicom, which will create a new behemoth in the advertising world, raised eyebrows for many reasons. One was that neither company hired a bulge-bracket investment bank, instead using Rothschild and Moelis & Company.

headline: Falling Rupee Puts Brakes on India’s Auto Industry
abstract: The auto industry has been hit by sluggish domestic demand as economic growth slows, and costs of imported auto components rise with the rupee’s depreciation.

headline: Daily Report: Proposing a ‘Nutrition Label’ for Mobile Apps
abstract: Some mobile apps could soon display information that allows consumers to decide at a glance whether the apps collect certain personal details from users or share user-specific data with entities like advertising networks, Natasha Singer reports.

headline: Disruptions: Hollywood, or Silicon Valley: Where’s the Money?
abstract: While the promise of huge paydays exists for both movies and tech start-ups, the safest bet is in more mundane markets.

headline: Visit to Washington Ends Era in U.S.- India Relations
abstract: The past and the future of the U.S. – India relationship.

headline: A Conversation With: Filmmaker Richie Mehta
abstract: Mr. Mehta on his recent film “Siddharth”, which traces a father’s journey for his missing son.

headline: China Internet Giant Buys Stake in Search Engine
abstract: Tencent Holdings, the biggest Internet company in China, said Monday that it had invested $448 million for a 36.5 percent stake in Sogou, a search engine, in a bid to keep pace with its rivals.

headline: Outsource Your Memory, With an App
abstract: Memoir, a new start-up, wants to take the place of that scrapbook on your smartphone by offering a way to store and organize photos, notes and more.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Revamps Its Corporate Structure
abstract: The company’s eight product divisions, satirized by some as being in a state of perpetual war, will be turned into four new ones arranged around broader themes.

headline: How to Run a Facebook Commerce Store
abstract: The founder of a women’s apparel and accessories business said she posted surprise coupons, ran sales two nights a week and made sure she had a customer service representative available on sale nights.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hullabaloo Over the ‘Hyperloop’
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Monday’s selections include early speculation on the so-called Hyperloop and the shutdown of a controversial London plan to track residents through their recycling.

headline: A Digital Diaper for Tracking Children’s Health
abstract: Diapers have traditionally had one primary sensor — the baby inside them, who cries when wet — but a company hopes to have its product collect data for a doctor.

headline: A Historian on a Film Set
abstract: A historian writes a Bollywood movie and explores the differences in non-fiction writing and filmmaking.

headline: Seeking Answers From Green Mountain Coffee
abstract: The sales figures at Green Mountain, the roaster behind the popular Keurig coffee makers, don’t seem to add up.

headline: Daily Report: Pandora Wins Court Victory Over Licenses to Stream Music
abstract: A federal judge has ruled that the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers cannot prevent Pandora Media from licensing all the songs in its catalog.

headline: Daily Report: Stores Use Cameras and Cellphone Signals to Track Shoppers
abstract: Retailers are increasingly using technology to gather data about in-store shoppers’ behavior and moods, using video surveillance and signals from cellphones and apps to learn information, Stephanie Clifford and Quentin Hardy report in The New York Times.

headline: Pure Storage Goes Global
abstract: The fast-moving storage company announces $150 million in new financing, which it will use to build a worldwide sales and support organization. That could be the most serious challenge yet to EMC, but also takes Pure into new territory.

headline: Argentine Technology Firm Plans I.P.O. on N.Y.S.E.
abstract: Globant, an Argentine software and information technology services company, has filed to go public on the New York Stock Exchange, in a move to broaden its reach.

headline: Motorola Ad Seems to Catch the ‘Made in U.S.A.’ Bug From Apple
abstract: In an advertisement promoting Motorola Mobility’s new smartphone, it borrows familiar themes from Apple, including the emphasis that it is made in America.

headline: Sheryl Sandberg Sells $91 Million of Facebook Stock
abstract: The No. 2 executive at the social network made her largest stock sale since the company’s initial public offering, although she still holds shares worth more than $1 billion.

headline: Fade to BlackBerry
abstract: Once the device of choice for a rich and mobile class, the BlackBerry is now seen as little more than a mark of white-collar servitude.

headline: Lessons for H.P. From Its Offspring
abstract: Agilent Technologies was considered the producer of nerdy scientific equipment when it was spun off from Hewlett-Packard in 1999, while H.P. was expanding. But Agilent has outperformed H.P. and is now splitting to create yet more value.

headline: Image of the Day: August 26
abstract: The 103rd anniversary of Mother Teresa’s birth was commemorated in Kolkata, West Bengal.

abstract: Gary M. Reiner, former chief information officer for General Electric, and James S. Turley, former chairman and chief executive of the accounting firm Ernst & Young, will join an expanded board.

headline: It’s Time for Gates to Part Ways With Microsoft
abstract: Bill Gates’s many talents don’t include effectiveness as chairman. Under his leadership, Microsoft’s board left Mr. Ballmer in place too long, the author writes.

headline: Steinway Says It Has Received Higher Bid
abstract: The maker of Steinway & Sons pianos says it has received an offer of $38 a share – nearly 9 percent higher than an earlier bid – from an unidentified affiliate of a large investment firm.

headline: Deal Talk in Cable TV
abstract: John C. Malone of Liberty Media is said to be weighing a deal for Time Warner Cable. | Criminal defense work, once shunned by top law firms, is looking increasingly lucrative. | Onyx Pharmaceuticals put itself up for sale after rejecting an unsolicited $10 billion takeover bid. | An updated analysis shows C.E.O.’s got a large raise last year.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Modern Warfare, and What Facebook Ads Say About You
abstract: Tuesday’s highlights from around the Web include an image of Syrian rebels fighting with the aid of an iPad. Plus, an investigation into what Facebook ads say about you, or why Facebook thinks you need to lose belly fat.

headline: It’s O.K. to Sell Your Business to the Highest Bidder
abstract: You want to believe that the buyers will treat your employees, customers and vendors with the same respect you did. But they probably won’t.

headline: 22 Children Die From Tainted Lunches at Indian School
abstract: The children complained that the food tasted odd, and after seeing the students get sick, teachers and administrators fled the school.

headline: In Kerala, Rehabilitated Killer Nurtures Mentally Challenged
abstract: Albin Mathew, 62, founded Santhi Bhavan Sarvodaya, a shelter for the mentally challenged after serving a jail term for murder.

headline: Daily Report: Alibaba Is Said to Shift I.P.O. Focus to U.S.
abstract: The Chinese Internet company Alibaba has ended talks with the Hong Kong stock exchange over an initial public offering and is now moving forward with plans to list in New York, a person close to Alibaba said on Wednesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Zuckerberg in a Suit, and Claims of an iPhone Fingerprint Scanner Hack
abstract: Monday’s highlights from around the Web include a critique of a suit that Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s co-founder, wore as he met with members of Congress. Plus, hackers claim to have broken the iPhone 5S’s new fingerprint recognition system.

headline: Policies on License Plate Readers Vary Widely, Says A.C.L.U.
abstract: Police agencies abide by a variety of policies on how long to retain license plate reader data and with whom to share it, posing privacy dangers, according to the American Civil Liberties Union.

headline: Malicious Software Poses as Video From a Facebook Friend
abstract: Attackers are using built-in features of the Chrome and Firefox Web browsers to install malicious software that can see everything stored in the browser, including saved passwords for e-mail and social network accounts, according to Italian security researchers.

headline: Dell Takeover Bid in Peril
abstract: Michael S. Dell’s effort to buy the company he founded has been thrown into jeopardy. | Standard & Poor’s is again winning business from banks by offering more favorable ratings. | Sergey Aleynikov, a fallen Goldman Sachs programmer, talks to Vanity Fair. | A jury is deciding whether a former trader, Fabrice P. Tourre, committed fraud.

headline: Image of the Day: August 1
abstract: Indian swimmer Sandeep Sejwal competing at a world championship in Barcelona, Spain.

headline: With Huge War Chests, Activist Investors Tackle Big Companies
abstract: Activist hedge funds have grown more ambitious, taking on larger companies and seeking long-term change over short-term profit, unlike raiders of the past.

headline: Daily Report: A Google-Built Smartphone Enters a Crowded Field
abstract: After lackluster results selling devices made by other companies, Google is giving hardware another try — this time with a smartphone made by a company it owns.

headline: India’s Electoral Politics Reignites Religious Hatreds
abstract: A comparison of economic and sectarian strife in India during the early 1990s and the country today.

headline: Apollo’s Energy I.P.O. Gives New Life to Quick Flips
abstract: Apollo Global Management is showing that private equity can still dig into its old bag of tricks.

headline: Charges Against 2 Traders Fault JPMorgan for Lack of Oversight
abstract: At a news conference announcing the arrest of two former traders at JPMorgan Chase, the authorities also criticized the bank’s oversight of the London office where they worked.

headline: In Markets’ Tuned-Up Machinery, Stubborn Ghosts Remain
abstract: Today’s automated stock exchanges are fast and efficient, so long as the computers are working. When things go awry, chaos can emerge quickly.

headline: Disruptions: How Driverless Cars Could Reshape Cities
abstract: While driverless cars might still seem like science fiction, people are considering what they could mean for the city of the future. The short answer is “a lot.”

headline: In the Affordable Care Act, Some Children Left Behind
abstract: Because of rules decided recently by the I.R.S., some workers could find family coverage all but impossible to obtain. Their best hope might be to ask their employers NOT to offer coverage.

headline: Grim World of Mumbai Rape Accused
abstract: Family members and neighbors of two of the five suspects react to the alleged involvement of the young men in the rape of a 22-year-old photojournalist.

headline: Can Minecraft Be Educational? Readers Respond
abstract: Parents and even a few children responded positively to a column on Minecraft and its benefits for kids as an educational tool — albeit one they are obsessed with.

headline: The Myspace Alumni That Left L.A. to Start Businesses
abstract: Gogobot and Mango Health emerged from the decline of Myspace but chose to locate in Silicon Valley.

headline: Once a Symbol of Brazil’s Might, Billionaire Sells Controlling Stake in a Company
abstract: Eike Batista has taken further steps toward dismantling his once high-flying empire. He is also said to have hired the Blackstone Group as a financial adviser for his petroleum concern.

headline: Apple’s Trademark of ‘iWatch’ Fuels Speculation
abstract: Apple, typically, is being secretive about its intentions, and may — or may not — be developing a watch that does more than tell time.

headline: Thai Billionaire Plans $2.3 Billion Infrastructure Fund I.P.O.
abstract: The True Corporation, a 3G and broadband network operator in Thailand, said it planned to use proceeds from the proposed spinoff of telecommunications assets to reduce debt.

headline: Congress Party Supports Creation of Telangana State
abstract: Telangana will be the 29th state of India after it goes through the legislative process.

headline: What Readers Found in Facebook’s ‘Other’ Folder
abstract: Sad messages, missed opportunities may end up in a folder meant to protect Facebook users from spam.

headline: Google Is Exploring an Alternative to Cookies for Ad Tracking
abstract: Google is considering an anonymous identifier for Chrome users, as advertisers fear that traditional methods of tracking users across the Web no longer work.

headline: Image of the Day: September 10
abstract: A one-horned rhinoceros with its 10-day-old calf at a zoo in Guwahati, Assam.

headline: What Icahn Has to Say
abstract: The billionaire investor discussed his fight over Dell, his brawl over Herbalife and even his wife’s opinions. At one point, he tried out an English accent.

headline: Titanium Fills Vital Role for Boeing and Russia
abstract: A Russian foundry produces large quantities of the strong, light metal, which is a major element in Boeing’s new jets.

headline: A Dizzying Condo Market in Toronto
abstract: Toronto’s effort to create a livable city through densely populated neighborhoods is a roaring success, but to what end?

headline: For South Sudan and the U.N., a Relationship of Growing Distrust
abstract: South Sudan, which the United Nations helped midwife into existence, has become one of the most dangerous theaters of operations for the world body.

headline: China Taps a Growing Phone Market
abstract: More phones are being designed for consumers in emerging markets, who are expected to account for most of the growth in smartphone sales.

headline: It’s Your Words Against Others’, in Games for the Mobile Screen
abstract: Besides the popular Words With Friends, app word games can be played with others over the Internet, or alone against the clock.

headline: Obama Tests Limits of Power in Syrian Conflict
abstract: President Obama’s approach to Syria is likely to create an important precedent in the often murky legal question of when presidents or nations may lawfully use military force.

headline: U.S. Official Predicts ‘War of Attrition’ Among Syrian Fighters After Strike
abstract: As a debate ensues on the severity of a possible strike on Syria, a State Department official said an attack would most likely not alter the military balance in the country.

headline: Despite Early Criticism, Apple’s iOS 7 Quickly Gains Traction
abstract: Despite harsh criticism from some designers, app developers and tech journalists about iOS 7, Apple’s redesigned mobile operating system, people are downloading the software in droves.

headline: Dow Index Drops Bank of America, Alcoa and H.P.
abstract: Alcoa, Bank of America and Hewlett-Packard — three stalwarts of corporate America that have fallen out of favor lately with investors — will be removed from the Dow Jones industrial average, to be replaced by Goldman Sachs, Visa and Nike.

headline: Today in Small Business: Frauds and Cyberattacks
abstract: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.

abstract: Morgan Stanley’s adjusted second-quarter earnings narrowly beat analysts’ estimates. | A special committee of Dell’s directors may delay a vote on the company’s proposed sale. | JPMorgan Chase is trying to avoid a showdown over accusations that it manipulated energy prices. | Nelson Peltz urges a merger of PepsiCo and Mondelez International.

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selections include a look at the evolution of Google Documents, and a way to see how much information can be gleaned from looking at a Gmail account but not inside the messages.

headline: Buy! Sell! Hold! Analysts Offer Different Views on Apple
abstract: After Apple extended sales of the iPhone to new foreign markets and offered a less expensive iPhone, some analysts downgraded the company’s stock while others came to its defense.

abstract: Ronald Coase, in his research and theories, found in labor unions many of the qualities valued by his more liberal colleagues, an economist writes.

abstract: Four big banks — with Goldman Sachs taking the lead — are said to have secured roles in Twitter’s highly anticipated initial public offering, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Dell Buyout Bid in Peril as Voting Rule Remains
abstract: A special committee of Dell Inc.’s board said on Wednesday that it would be willing to accept the latest takeover bid by its founder, worth $13.75 a share, if he dropped his demand for a change to the voting rules.

headline: Rocket Fuel Prices I.P.O. at Top of Revised Range
abstract: Rocket Fuel, an advertising technology company that relies on artificial intelligence, priced its initial public offering on Thursday at the top of its expectations, garnering $116 million in proceeds.

headline: Fighting in Southern Philippines Kills 8
abstract: Less than a year after a major peace deal in the south, fighting between government forces and rebels left out of the agreement paralyzed a city of 800,000.

headline: Google Makes New Offer to Settle Its European Union Antitrust Case
abstract: The Internet giant said it made a second attempt to settle an antitrust inquiry it faces in Europe over accusations that it abuses its dominance in Internet search and advertising.

headline: Clear Channel-Warner Music Deal Rewrites the Rules on Royalties
abstract: Clear Channel will pay royalties for the first time to performers and a record label when songs are played on its radio stations. In return for the record label, Warner Music, will discount the high cost to stream music online.

headline: Defection Hurts Polish Premier Amid Protests
abstract: A country that enjoyed growth through Europe’s debt crisis is now feeling the pain of a slowing economy.

headline: Syrian Rebels Say Saudi Arabia Is Stepping Up Weapons Deliveries
abstract: Even though American and British intelligence have increased weapons deliveries to rebels in Syria, the Russian proposal on Syria has left many rebel groups feeling abandoned.

abstract: The military strategy that the Obama administration is considering is not linked to its larger diplomatic strategy of persuading President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to yield power.

headline: Rwanda Warns Congo After Shells Hit Its Territory
abstract: The escalating conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo threatened to embroil Rwanda after a woman there was killed and her baby wounded in shelling, Rwanda’s government said.

headline: Iraqis, Looking Across Border, See Replays of Past and Fears for the Future
abstract: As the debate over military action in Syria has unfolded in the West, Iraqis see the fate of the two countries as inextricably intertwined.

headline: South Korea Pledges Aid to the North
abstract: South Korea promised $8.4 million worth of humanitarian aid to North Korea on Monday, the latest effort to improve relations on the peninsula.

headline: Obama Seeks Approval by Congress for Strike in Syria
abstract: President Obama abruptly changed course by asking lawmakers, who are not due to return to town for more than a week, to give him authorization before he launches a limited military strike against Syria.

abstract: The leak at a frozen storage and logistics business that sent stinging fumes into nearby residential areas also injured at least 25 people, some seriously.

abstract: A grandson of the creator of the Red Bull energy drink admitted to fatally striking a police officer with his Ferrari and dragging his dead body down a Bangkok street.

abstract: A far younger campaign reporter now feeds a never-ending news cycle named Twitter.

headline: Huge Summer for Hollywood, but With Few Blockbusters
abstract: Ticket revenue in North America totaled $4.71 billion, up 10.2 percent from last summer, but a competition glut hurt films that could have been hits in a thinner field.

abstract: Syria’s government on Sunday said President Obama’s decision to have Congress weigh in on any military action was a sign of weakness, while rebel leaders expressed anger and disappointment.

headline: Buy! Sell! Hold! Analysts Offer Different Views on Apple
abstract: After Apple extended sales of the iPhone to new foreign markets and offered a less expensive iPhone, some analysts downgraded the company’s stock while others came to its defense.

headline: The ‘Coase Theorem’ and Labor Unions
abstract: Ronald Coase, in his research and theories, found in labor unions many of the qualities valued by his more liberal colleagues, an economist writes.

headline: Wall Street Gears Up for a Twitter I.P.O.
abstract: Four big banks — with Goldman Sachs taking the lead — are said to have secured roles in Twitter’s highly anticipated initial public offering, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Dell Buyout Bid in Peril as Voting Rule Remains
abstract: A special committee of Dell Inc.’s board said on Wednesday that it would be willing to accept the latest takeover bid by its founder, worth $13.75 a share, if he dropped his demand for a change to the voting rules.

headline: Rocket Fuel Prices I.P.O. at Top of Revised Range
abstract: Rocket Fuel, an advertising technology company that relies on artificial intelligence, priced its initial public offering on Thursday at the top of its expectations, garnering $116 million in proceeds.

headline: Ex-Leader Weds, Complicating Czech Bribe Case
abstract: Former Prime Minister Petr Necas and his onetime chief of staff, Jana Nagyova, in the spotlight of a corruption investigation, are said to have wed secretly.

headline: Housing Recovery Seems Still on Track
abstract: Home values and home prices are rising, according to several surveys.

headline: Iran’s New President Preaches Tolerance in First U.N. Appearance
abstract: In a widely awaited speech, Hassan Rouhani denounced as a form of violence the Western sanctions imposed on Iran and said nuclear weapons would never be part of its future.

headline: Rules Sought for Workplace Wellness Questionnaires
abstract: Representative Louise M. Slaughter wants the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to issue guidelines on employee wellness questionnaires to prevent workplace discrimination.

headline: In Indonesia, a Governor at Home on the Streets
abstract: As Indonesians look to their next presidential election, many are talking about a local governor who has demonstrated an unusually common touch with the people.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: More colorful epithets for the companies you love to hate.

headline: For Obama, an Evolving Doctrine on Foreign Policy
abstract: President Obama told world leaders on Tuesday that he was devoting the rest of his presidency to a negotiated end to the Iran confrontation, and creating a separate state for the Palestinians.

headline: Attention Switches to Investigation of Kenyan Mall Siege
abstract: Investigators began sifting through rubble, studied closed-circuit television footage and brought in more resources to identify the militants who laid siege to an upscale mall in Nairobi.

headline: Iran’s Leader, Denouncing Holocaust, Stirs Dispute
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani’s condemnation of the Holocaust has set off a political storm, landing him in precisely the kind of tangled dispute he had hoped to avoid.

headline: Mexico: Stranded Tourists Airlifted From Acapulco
abstract: Mexico began airlifting hundreds of stranded tourists to Mexico City from Acapulco after a tropical storm flooded highways, the airport and some hotels.

headline: Despite Early Criticism, Apple’s iOS 7 Quickly Gains Traction
abstract: Despite harsh criticism from some designers, app developers and tech journalists about iOS 7, Apple’s redesigned mobile operating system, people are downloading the software in droves.

headline: Dow Index Drops Bank of America, Alcoa and H.P.
abstract: Alcoa, Bank of America and Hewlett-Packard — three stalwarts of corporate America that have fallen out of favor lately with investors — will be removed from the Dow Jones industrial average, to be replaced by Goldman Sachs, Visa and Nike.

headline: Today in Small Business: Frauds and Cyberattacks
abstract: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.

headline: Pipeline Reopens in Libya, Bolstering Oil Production
abstract: A striking militia opened the valves on a pipeline between two major western oil fields and Mediterranean port terminals.

headline: U.S. Denies Trying to Bar Venezuelan President From Airspace
abstract: American officials gave permission for President Nicolás Maduro to fly over Puerto Rico  and denied that they had tried to bar Mr. Maduro from United States airspace.

headline: British Retailers Accused of Fixing Bra Prices
abstract: The Office of Fair Trading said John Lewis, Debenhams and House of Fraser had colluded with DB Apparel over the prices of sports bras.

headline: A Surface Calm, Punctured by Artillery and Weary Arguments
abstract: Syria’s capital is now a city of checkpoints, new arrivals and a pervasive sense of war weariness, where even those of opposite views seem worn out by their differences.

headline: Putting an Estate Value on the Assets Unique to You
abstract: The unknowable vagaries of time can complicate the appraisal of the assets in an estate — and yet appraise you must, or risk incurring penalties from the I.R.S.

headline: De Niro to Replace James Gandolfini in HBO Drama
abstract: Robert De Niro, the Oscar-winning actor, has agreed to take over the part played by Mr. Gandolfini in the pilot of “Criminal Justice.” Mr. Gandolfini died in June.

headline: British Leader Is Under Attack From Right and Center
abstract: Going into this weekend’s Tory conference, Britain’s prime minister, David Cameron, faces a right-wing uprising among legislators who see him as weak on issues like gay marriage and immigration.

headline: Japan’s Leader Gives No Ground in Islands Dispute
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said he was open to dialogue with China about disputed islands in the South China Sea but that Japan owns them.

headline: Somali Militants Mixing Business and Terror
abstract: The Shabab, which claimed responsibility for the deadly mall siege in Nairobi, Kenya, makes money through illegal endeavors and even employs a team of accountants.

headline: U.N. Investigates More Alleged Chemical Attacks in Syria
abstract: Inspectors were looking into reports that chemical weapons were used seven times, including three after the Aug. 21 attack that set off an international crisis.
