headline: Time-Shifted Viewing, Plans for Las Vegas and Bossy Little Girls
abstract: Highlights of the 10th annual Advertising Week, including a panel discussion on a TV network’s advertising plans and a conversation with Sheryl Sandberg, of Facebook.

headline: Why Judges Are Scowling at Banks
abstract: District court judges are not generally known as flamethrowers, but some seem to be losing patience with banks in cases involving lending practices.

headline: Helping Bands Play to the Crowd, Long Before the Show
abstract: For musicians, crowd-sourced fund-raising is lessening the financial risk of performing in new markets.

headline: U.S. and Iran  Agree to Speed Talks to Defuse Nuclear Issue
abstract: President Obama said he saw the basis for a deal after speaking on the phone with President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, the first discussion between leaders of the two countries since 1979.

headline: Cuba to Let Its Athletes Play Abroad
abstract: Cuba, a sports-crazed island, has long sought to keep its athletes at home in quasi-amateur leagues, usually prohibiting them from cashing in on multimillion-dollar contracts abroad.

headline: ‘Big Bang’ Reinforces Its Status as Biggest Hit on Network TV
abstract: The CBS sitcom had an audience of almost 19 million, and the highest rating on any series this season. The audience for Michael J. Fox’s return was relatively modest.

headline: Housing Market Is Heating Up, if Not Yet Bubbling
abstract: A home-buyer survey suggests that while the nation isn’t in a housing bubble, there are some troubling signs that it’s heading toward one.

headline: Have-Nots Squeezed and Stacked in Hong Kong
abstract: In a city with some of the highest living costs in the world, those at the bottom of the income ladder increasingly resort to cupboardlike living spaces, a dozen or more to an apartment.

headline: Alibaba Chastises Hong Kong Exchange
abstract: A top executive at the company, which bypassed Hong Kong for its possible I.P.O., says the Asian exchange is in danger of being overtaken by other markets.

headline: A Little More Legroom, Priced as an Upgrade
abstract: Airlines have been busily adding fees on most aspects of flying, spurred by spectacular revenue increases, and now they are charging premiums for seating.

abstract: The constant distraction of restricting calorie intake strains the mental capacity of dieters; in a similar way, poverty is a strain on the poor.

abstract: United has resurrected its “fly the friendly skies” tagline.

headline: 2 Top Technology Writers Are Leaving Dow Jones
abstract: Walt Mossberg and Kara Swisher, co-editors of the All Things Digital news site, will depart at the end of the year.

headline: When Trying to Follow Rules Isn’t Enough
abstract: As JPMorgan’s general counsel, Stephen Cutler tried to create a culture of compliance. The effort couldn’t stop the “London whale” matter and other regulatory woes.

headline: Nielsen Will Add Mobile Viewership to Ratings
abstract: The company’s program, which would begin in fall 2014, should soothe television executives eager to get credit for fans who don’t use ordinary TVs.

headline: Labour Party Finding Fault With Its Leader
abstract: Ed Miliband, who became the leader of the British Labour Party three years ago after its election defeat, has failed to convince the public that he is prime ministerial material.

headline: You Didn’t Get the Job? Maybe It’s a Good Thing
abstract: Someone who is solicited for a job with a former employer, then gets only silence, might want to find out what went wrong.

headline: European Union Officer Is Killed in Kosovo
abstract: The victim, a Lithuanian customs officer, was part of a European mission that oversees judicial affairs in the tense region.

headline: Taliban Are Said to Attack Afghan Police
abstract: The reports were a sign of growing casualty rates among forces in Afghanistan, but they were disputed by the government.

headline: Senior Egyptian Police Officer Is Killed in a Raid on Islamists Near Cairo
abstract: Gunmen fatally shot the senior officer and wounded 10 others during a raid by Egyptian security forces to flush out Islamist militants hiding on the outskirts of Cairo.

abstract: Iran’s new foreign minister is to meet with the five permanent Security Council members and Germany this week at the United Nations, according to their envoy.

abstract: The world’s transport ministers are gathering this week to tackle the growing problem of greenhouse gases emitted by airliners, a contentious issue with no easy solution.

abstract: The German election showed that above all, the country appreciates the stable, safe course that Chancellor Angela Merkel charted during her first two terms.

abstract: A direct public offering describes a public securities offering similar to an I.P.O., but with one big difference: There is no need to hire an investment bank.

headline: Pivot TV Pitches to Young Viewers
abstract: A channel for young people called Pivot, which will become available in 40 million homes on Thursday, aims for “entertainment that inspires and compels social change.”

headline: Dispute Blocks Hollywood’s Share of Chinese Box Office
abstract: A disagreement has taken root over whether to apply a new tax in China to the share of movie ticket sales that is owed to American film studios.

abstract: Two months after Mexico’s president sent troops to Michoacán, gunmen killed one of the Mexican Navy’s most senior officers, raising the stakes in a battle for control of the area.

headline: A Great Manager Should Expect a Peaceful Vacation
abstract: Christopher J. Williams, C.E.O. of the Williams Capital Group, says that a manager whose vacations are interrupted should do a better job of developing the team.

headline: Essence Magazine Names New Top Editor
abstract: This is its fifth editor in 13 years. The last one had been dismissed in February.

headline: ‘The Croods’ Helps DreamWorks Animation Increase Quarterly Profit
abstract: The company reported net income of $22.2 million, or 26 cents a share, up from $12.8 million a year ago and better than analysts’ forecasts of 20 cents a share.

abstract: Mr. Lee created Blanton’s Single Barrel for Buffalo Trace Distillery in 1984 and is credited with reviving Kentucky whiskey’s reputation.

headline: Harsh Self-Assessment as Cuba Looks Within
abstract: President Raúl Castro and many of his citizens are bemoaning a loss of culture and civility in the nation.

headline: Biden Arrives in India in Effort to Improve Relations
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s visit, part of an effort to portray the Obama administration’s good will, is the first by a vice president in nearly 30 years.

headline: Chinese Search for Infant Formula Goes Global
abstract: Fueled by distrust of domestic brands, Chinese parents are buying up foreign-made infant milk powder, and that has led to shortages in at least a half-dozen other countries.

headline: Former Time Warner Executive Is Coming Back to Run Time Inc.
abstract: Joseph A. Ripp is being installed as the new leader at Time Inc.’s magazine division ahead of its spinoff into a separate company.

headline: Wave of Violence Continues in Iraq
abstract: A suicide bomber drove into an army patrol on Monday, killing 13 people in Mosul, and on Sunday night, 29 people were killed in coordinated attacks on two prisons in Baghdad.

headline: Setbacks From Within in Struggle to End Kashmir’s Violence
abstract: The discovery of an unexploded grenade outside the police station in Thathri, Kashmir, had some people fearing that the recent relative quiet in the region might not last.

headline: Congressman Vows to Introduce Bill on Radio Royalties
abstract: Representative Melvin L. Watt, a Democrat from North Carolina, says the measure is an effort to get payment for record companies and artists whose music is played on AM or FM radio.

headline: Aid to Egypt Can Keep Flowing, Despite Overthrow, White House Decides
abstract: Administration officials have decided they are not legally required to determine whether the overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt was a coup.

headline: Samsung’s Profit Rises, but So Does the Competition
abstract: Samsung said net income in the second quarter rose to $6.9 billion, an increase of 50 percent, but it expected smartphone sales growth to slow down.

abstract: The approach illustrated the European Union’s strategy of trying to rein in Israeli actions that undermine the Middle East peace process, while maintaining good relations with Israel.

abstract: People can decline to receive Amber Alerts and alerts for “imminent threats” on their phones, but not alerts issued by the president’s office.

abstract: The Duchess of Cambridge and Prince William took turns cradling the newest royal heir in their arms to the screaming delight of onlookers.

abstract: Angela Merkel has pledged to reduce the bureaucracy affecting citizens, but some in an area hit by flooding say getting government help has been slowed by onerous requirements.

headline: Paul English of Kayak, on Nurturing New Ideas
abstract: The co-founder and chief technology officer of Kayak, the travel Web site, says “no innovation happens with 10 people in a room.”

headline: Leap Motion Controller, Great Hardware in Search of Great Software
abstract: The controller promises to let you control your computer with hand motions, and the hardware does that, but its software is scattershot, inconsistent and frustrating.

abstract: The audacity of the assaults on Sunday, in which hundreds of inmates escaped, underscored the deterioration of Iraq’s stability in recent months.

headline: North Korea Said to Stop Construction at Rocket Site
abstract: Satellite images show that work has stopped on a new launching pad and missile assembly building, a research institute reported.

headline: She Turned Her Upspeak Down a Notch
abstract: A freelance journalist was tired of sources thinking that she sounded like a little girl on the phone. So she set out to change her voice.

abstract: The decline in bread consumption is so worrisome that a nationwide campaign is championing bread as promoting good health, good conversation and French civilization.

headline: Hezbollah Makes Vow to Step Up Syria Fight
abstract: Hasan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, accused radical Sunnis of orchestrating a car bombing that killed 24 in Beirut.

headline: U.N. Team Arrives in Syria to Assess Possible Chemical Arms Use
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad and rebels seeking to oust him have accused each other of deploying chemical weapons.

headline: Despite Early Criticism, Apple’s iOS 7 Quickly Gains Traction
abstract: Despite harsh criticism from some designers, app developers and tech journalists about iOS 7, Apple’s redesigned mobile operating system, people are downloading the software in droves.

headline: Dow Index Drops Bank of America, Alcoa and H.P.
abstract: Alcoa, Bank of America and Hewlett-Packard — three stalwarts of corporate America that have fallen out of favor lately with investors — will be removed from the Dow Jones industrial average, to be replaced by Goldman Sachs, Visa and Nike.

headline: Today in Small Business: Frauds and Cyberattacks
abstract: Another blow to dozens of businesses on the Jersey Shore. Updates on the looming financial crises. And a Home Depot wedding proposal.

headline: Morgan Stanley Beats Estimates
abstract: Morgan Stanley’s adjusted second-quarter earnings narrowly beat analysts’ estimates. | A special committee of Dell’s directors may delay a vote on the company’s proposed sale. | JPMorgan Chase is trying to avoid a showdown over accusations that it manipulated energy prices. | Nelson Peltz urges a merger of PepsiCo and Mondelez International.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Origin of Google Docs, and Spying on Your Own E-Mail
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selections include a look at the evolution of Google Documents, and a way to see how much information can be gleaned from looking at a Gmail account but not inside the messages.

headline: Buy! Sell! Hold! Analysts Offer Different Views on Apple
abstract: After Apple extended sales of the iPhone to new foreign markets and offered a less expensive iPhone, some analysts downgraded the company’s stock while others came to its defense.

headline: The ‘Coase Theorem’ and Labor Unions
abstract: Ronald Coase, in his research and theories, found in labor unions many of the qualities valued by his more liberal colleagues, an economist writes.

headline: Wall Street Gears Up for a Twitter I.P.O.
abstract: Four big banks — with Goldman Sachs taking the lead — are said to have secured roles in Twitter’s highly anticipated initial public offering, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Dell Buyout Bid in Peril as Voting Rule Remains
abstract: A special committee of Dell Inc.’s board said on Wednesday that it would be willing to accept the latest takeover bid by its founder, worth $13.75 a share, if he dropped his demand for a change to the voting rules.

headline: Rocket Fuel Prices I.P.O. at Top of Revised Range
abstract: Rocket Fuel, an advertising technology company that relies on artificial intelligence, priced its initial public offering on Thursday at the top of its expectations, garnering $116 million in proceeds.

headline: U.S. Diplomats, Relieved After Libyan Attack, Are Reinstated
abstract: Four officials who were placed on administrative leave after the deadly attack last year on the United States diplomatic post in Benghazi have been reinstated and given new assignments.

headline: South Sudan: Commander Arrested
abstract: The president ordered the arrest of a high-ranking army commander over suspected violations of human rights, a military spokesman said Tuesday.

headline: Myanmar’s Muslim Minority Confronts Fear and Mistrust
abstract: Violence has flared after decades of peaceful coexistence with the Buddhist majority, and Muslims say they are afraid of more attacks.

headline: In Cargo Delivery, the Three-Wheelers That Could
abstract: A small freight company in Portland, Ore., makes its deliveries not with semitrailers but with electric-assisted trikes.

headline: A New Tool Aims to Help Facebook Users Dig Deep
abstract: Facebook is planning to introduce Graph Search, a tool to help users sift the volumes of information on the site, and its success is important to the company’s future.

headline: Where Mandela Kept Hope, Guide Tells Their Shared Saga
abstract: Ahmed Kathrada, a longtime anti-apartheid activist and fellow inmate of Nelson Mandela, has shown Robben Island to world leaders and celebrities.

headline: British Company Applies for Shale Gas Fracking Permit
abstract: Cuadrilla Resources announced on Friday that it was applying to hydraulically fracture an exploration well in Lancashire, England.

headline: Touch Screens Are Tested for Piloting Passenger Jets
abstract: Pilots could soon start dispensing with buttons, trackballs and keypads in favor of icons that can be dragged, slide-to-scroll menus and even voice commands.

headline: Two Former Popes to Be Made Saints
abstract: Pope John Paul II and Pope John XXIII will be made saints, the Vatican said on Friday, announcing that a second miracle had been attributed to John Paul.

headline: In Europe, Greener Transit on Existing Infrastructure
abstract: As cities aim to cut emissions, Vienna has introduced a network of electric buses whose batteries can be charged quickly using the city’s tram equipment.

abstract: Despite harsh criticism from some designers, app developers and tech journalists about iOS 7, Apple’s redesigned mobile operating system, people are downloading the software in droves.

headline: A Sports Agent With Hollywood in His Blood
abstract: His grandfather was a mighty Hollywood force, but Casey Wasserman has chosen the sports world for making his mark, with a rapidly growing management and marketing firm.

headline: Even as Army Seizes Power, Egyptians Claim Revolt as Their Own
abstract: In protest squares and elsewhere in Egypt, it was hard to find much hand-wringing about the circumstances that forced President Mohamed Morsi from power.

headline: For Islamists, Dire Lessons on Politics and Power
abstract: The overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi demonstrated for some the futility of democracy, but others faulted the leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood for reaching too fast for so many levers of power.

headline: Malaysia Denies Entry to Journalist
abstract: The journalist, Clare Rewcastle Brown, is the sister-in-law of former Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain and the founder of news outlets that have taken on the Malaysian government.

headline: On Tape, Murdoch Criticizes Hacking Inquiry, Broadcaster Says
abstract: A British station broadcast what appeared to be a recording of Rupert Murdoch criticizing the police investigation of Britain’s phone hacking scandal as “totally incompetent.”

headline: European Central Bank Commits to Low Rate
abstract: Mario Draghi, the bank’s president, said on Thursday that interest rates will stay low “for an extended period of time.”

headline: South and North Korea Agree to Discuss Shared Industrial Park
abstract: A South Korean-run industrial complex in North Korea has been idle since April, when tensions between the two nations reached a high point.

headline: In Portugal, a Protector of a People Is Honored
abstract: A foundation is trying to bring recognition to Aristides de Sousa Mendes, a diplomat who helped thousands of people to escape Nazi persecution and later died in poverty.

headline: Militant Vows to Attack Winter Olympics
abstract: Russia’s most wanted terrorist, Doku Umarov, said he would attack the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi as retribution for Muslim deaths in the Russian conquest of the Caucasus.

headline: China Says Foreign Makers of Baby Formula May Be Fixing Prices
abstract: The government said prices for milk powder made outside China were up 30 percent since 2008, when several babies died after drinking Chinese-made formula.

headline: China Eases Bank Loan Rules, in a Step Toward a Market-Driven Economy
abstract: China’s central bank announced interest rate reforms, removing minimum rates banks may charge for loans in a step toward more market-driven credit pricing.

headline: At Hotels, New Ideas Mix With the Tried and True
abstract: Innovation is being encouraged at the local level, in a push to get new ideas in front of guests and learn from their feedback.

headline: Mediating as French Culture and Economics Collide
abstract: Aurélie Filippetti, a novelist, is finding new kinds of criticism as France’s minister of culture and communication.

headline: Inspirations All Around (and a Gym Downstairs)
abstract: Sarah Robb O’Hagan, president of Equinox Fitness, has her office just above the top floor of one of its health clubs.

headline: 50 Years of Tough Questions and ‘Thank You, Mr. President’
abstract: Ms. Thomas covered every president from John F. Kennedy to Barack Obama, but her career ended ignominiously over remarks she made about Israeli Jews.

headline: Australia Adopts Tough Measures to Curb Asylum Seekers
abstract: A policy to deal with a record number of asylum seekers would deny permission to settle in the country to anyone who arrived by boat without a visa.

headline: Google Results Show Struggle With Mobile
abstract: The second-quarter income announcement showed the desktop search business continued to slow, while ad prices fell.

headline: Weak PC Market Catches Up to Microsoft
abstract: The company blamed the declining personal computer market and disappointing sales of its Surface RT tablet for missing Wall Street’s quarterly forecasts.

headline: Thousands Gather to Bury a Slain Tunisian Politician
abstract: Demonstrators gathered for the funeral of Mohamed Brahmi in a show of force against the government, which many blame for the assassination.

headline: North Korea Showcases Its Military Might at a Mass Rally
abstract: The North Korean military marked the anniversary Saturday of the end of the Korean War by showing what may be its first intercontinental missiles at a parade in Pyongyang.

headline: G.M. Dismisses Executives as India Begins Investigating Recall of Vehicles
abstract: An inquiry started this week into the recall of 114,000 Chevrolet Tavera utility vehicles.

headline: Soldiers’ Mass Execution Reported by Syria Group
abstract: Extremists in Syria’s insurgency killed 150 government fighters, including 51 who were executed after they had surrendered, a monitoring group said.

headline: Some Investing Stories Sound Good Until You Analyze Them
abstract: Stories about young real estate investors may be persuasive, the author writes, but deciding if similar actions would be good for us is crucial.

headline: Trying to Pierce a Wall Street Fog
abstract: Europe has taken the lead in challenging the market for credit default swaps. And a handful of pension funds have filed two suits against the big banks that dominate it.

headline: The Argus App Can Help to Keep You Fit
abstract: Argus, a free fitness app, can help track your activity and hold you accountable, with the help of some other apps.

headline: 6 Sentenced to Life in Rape of Tourist in India
abstract: A court sentenced six men to life in prison for the gang rape of a Swiss tourist last March, one of several highly publicized cases that stirred public anger over sexual assaults in India.

headline: Colombian Rebels Holding an American
abstract: The FARC said that it took a former American service member hostage last month and that it now plans to release him as a sign of good will during continuing peace talks.

headline: U.S. Intelligence Official Says Syrian War Could Last for Years
abstract: A senior American intelligence official on Saturday warned that the Syrian conflict could last “many, many months to multiple years.”

headline: Ultra-Orthodox Candidates Elected as Israel’s Chief Rabbis
abstract: Two candidates backed by ultra-Orthodox parties were elected as Israel’s chief rabbis, defeating a rabbi who had promised, in an aggressive campaign, to transform the troubled rabbinate.

headline: Egyptian General Calls for Mass Protests
abstract: The directive from Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi raised the possibility of another Friday of dueling protests with supporters of deposed President Mohamed Morsi.

abstract: Despite harsh criticism from some designers, app developers and tech journalists about iOS 7, Apple’s redesigned mobile operating system, people are downloading the software in droves.

headline: Syrian Opposition Leader Says He Would Meet Assad Officials
abstract: Ahmad al-Jarba, president of the National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces, says he is prepared to attend a peace conference in Geneva without preconditions.

headline: Siemens to Oust Chief After String of Setbacks
abstract: Peter Löscher, head of the electronics and engineering conglomerate since 2007, is taking the blame for a series of missteps that have plagued Siemens last year.

headline: Wave of Car Bombs Kills Dozens in Iraq
abstract: A surge of violence in Iraq claimed more victims on Monday, when 15 car bombs killed at least 46 people and injured many more, security officials said.

headline: Other Nations Offer a Lesson to Egypt’s Military Leaders
abstract: A look at other Muslim countries that have struggled with democratic transitions provides a kind of warning to Egypt’s military leaders.

headline: Gorky Park, Once Drab, Now Glows
abstract: The park has transformed over the past two years into an extravagant urban recreational space that offers Muscovites a respite from the intense political pressures of Russia.

headline: Thai Officials Play Down Effects of Oil Spill
abstract: In Thailand's third-largest oil spill, the government was quick to try to declare the affected areas safe for tourists, with one official going as far to swim in one of the worst-contaminated areas.

headline: Nuclear Operator Raises Alarm on Crisis
abstract: Tepco, the operator of Japan’s tsunami-hit nuclear power plant, said there were more than 200,000 tons of radioactive water in tanks vulnerable to leaks, adding to a list of problems.

headline: Russia Urges Syria to Cooperate in Chemical Weapons Inquiry
abstract: Moscow said it was now up to the opposition to guarantee safe access for United Nations investigators to examine the site of a suspected chemical weapons attack near Damascus.

headline: Outcry Grows Against British Housing Plan
abstract: Help to Buy, in which the government either offers interest-free credit or guarantees part of the property loan, has come under criticism from those who say it could create a real estate bubble.

headline: From Italy, a Vintage Redolent of Horrors
abstract: The Simon Wiesenthal Center has called on distributors to stop handling a line of Italian wines that carry labels that portray Hitler and sundry members of the Nazi hierarchy.
